Class SenderTransport

java.lang.Object
  SenderTransport

public class SenderTransport
extends java.lang.Object

A class which represents the receiver transport layer

Method Detail

gbn

public void gbn(Message msg)

gbnReceive

public void gbnReceive(Packet pkt)

gbnResend

public void gbnResend(int nextAck)

initialize

public void initialize()
This routine will be called once, before any of your other sender routines are called. It can be used to do any required initialization

receiveMessage

public void receiveMessage(Packet pkt)
where packet is a structure of type pkt. This routine will be called whenever a packet sent from the receiver arrives at the sender. pkt is the (possibly corrupted) packet sent from the sender.

sendMessage

public void sendMessage(Message msg)
where message contains data to be sent to the B-side. This routine will be called whenever the upper layer at the sending side has a message to send. It is the job of your protocol to insure that the data in such a message is delivered in-order, and correctly, to the receiving side upper layer

setProtocol

public void setProtocol(int n)

setTimeLine

public void setTimeLine(Timeline tl)

setWindowSize

public void setWindowSize(int n)

tcp

public void tcp(Message msg)
Works much the same way as gbn as far as sending. Packet is simply created and sent on.

tcpReceive

public void tcpReceive(Packet pkt)

tcpResend

public void tcpResend(int nextSeq)

timerExpired

public void timerExpired()
This routine will be called when the sender's timer expires (thus generating a timer interrupt). You'll probably want to use this routine to control the retransmission of packets. See starttimer()and stoptimer() below for how the timer is started and stopped
